docs.text: My Notes For mkdocs tutorial For full documentation visit mkdocs.org . Commands mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project. mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server. mkdocs build - Build the documentation site. mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit. Table of Contents CSS Notes Django Docker Javascript React Git Branches Reversing Changes in Git Advanced Feature, Selecting commits Excercises 4.1 Grabbing Just 1 Commit 4.2 Juggling Commits 4.3 Juggling Commits #2 5.1 Rebasing over 9000 Todo List Git Resources Learning Git Interactive Conversational Git Blog Git commands git init - To initialize git in folder git clone [github repo] git add [. or folder/ or filename] git commit -m 'message' - This is to add changes locally git push and git pull - Push and pull remote repo *** git pull is the same as running git fetch and git merge git status - Shows what changes have been made git log or gitk - Shows info git describe [ref or master or branch] - Use to figure out where you are if using tags or branches Branches Using merges and basic branching Git Documentation Rebasing guide documentation Rebasing best practices w/ team Rebasing Blog git checkout -b [branch name] - This is the same as Git Branch [branch name], then Git checkout [branch name] git checkout [commit or HEAD^ or tag] - This detaches head git merge [branch name] - Use merge branch [branch name], run it in master branch git mergetool - Tool for resolving merge conflicts git push --set-upstream origin [branch name] - THIS sets branch to be uploaded to Github git branch -v - View branches and last commit git branch -d [branch-name] - THIS DELETES A BRANCH git rebase master - If we are in [working branch name] this puts it on top of master linearly. git rebase [branch name] - Run in master git rebase [master] [branch name] - To rebase new branch into master git rebase –abort - IF we run into merge problems, this resets to right before moving upwards one commit, then two ^,^^ moving upwards 3 commits ~3 Example: git checkout HEAD or [branch name]^ git branch -f master [HEAD~2 or tag or commit] - This force moves the master branch to 2 commits ago. Reversing changes in Git git reset HEAD~1 - This reverts the branch backwards as if the commit never happened. Work for local branch. git revert [branch name or tag] - This creates a new commit with old info under last commit. Use for remote branch Advanced feature, selecting commits git cherry-pick [commit names] - This copies the commits into master Example: git checkout master - Change into master branch from working branch Example: git cherry-pick [commit] - Gets only that commit git rebase -i HEAD~3 - This opens an interactive cherry picking gui Example: git rebase -i HEAD~3 - This gives the option to include what commits run on working branch Example: git branch -f master [tag or commit] - This forces master branch to a commit Excercises From the Learning Git Interactive 4.1 Grabbing Just 1 Commit git checkout master; git cherry-pick C4; or git rebase -i master; git branch -f master c4; 4.2 Juggling Commits git rebase -i HEAD^^; git checkout newImage; git rebase caption; git commit --amend git rebase -i HEAD^^ git checkout caption git rebase newImage git branch -f master c3''; 4.3 Juggling Commits 2 git checkout master git cherry-pick c2 git commit --amend git cherry-pick c3 5.1 Rebasing over 9000 git rebase master bugfix git rebase bugFix side git rebase side another git rebase another master Todo List [ ] Add promises section to Javascript [ ] Work on react section [ ] Reformat and space Javascript section [ ] Reformat and space React Section [x] Make a docker page [ ] Fill bootstrap page

docs.text: Resources Learning Git Interactive Conversational Git Blog Git commands git init - To initialize git in folder git clone [github repo] git add [. or folder/ or filename] git commit -m 'message' - This is to add changes locally git push and git pull - Push and pull remote repo *** git pull is the same as running git fetch and git merge git status - Shows what changes have been made git log or gitk - Shows info git describe [ref or master or branch] - Use to figure out where you are if using tags or branches
docs.title: Git

docs.text: Using merges and basic branching Git Documentation Rebasing guide documentation Rebasing best practices w/ team Rebasing Blog git checkout -b [branch name] - This is the same as Git Branch [branch name], then Git checkout [branch name] git checkout [commit or HEAD^ or tag] - This detaches head git merge [branch name] - Use merge branch [branch name], run it in master branch git mergetool - Tool for resolving merge conflicts git push --set-upstream origin [branch name] - THIS sets branch to be uploaded to Github git branch -v - View branches and last commit git branch -d [branch-name] - THIS DELETES A BRANCH git rebase master - If we are in [working branch name] this puts it on top of master linearly. git rebase [branch name] - Run in master git rebase [master] [branch name] - To rebase new branch into master git rebase –abort - IF we run into merge problems, this resets to right before moving upwards one commit, then two ^,^^ moving upwards 3 commits ~3 Example: git checkout HEAD or [branch name]^ git branch -f master [HEAD~2 or tag or commit] - This force moves the master branch to 2 commits ago.
docs.title: Branches

docs.text: git reset HEAD~1 - This reverts the branch backwards as if the commit never happened. Work for local branch. git revert [branch name or tag] - This creates a new commit with old info under last commit. Use for remote branch
docs.title: Reversing changes in Git

docs.text: git cherry-pick [commit names] - This copies the commits into master Example: git checkout master - Change into master branch from working branch Example: git cherry-pick [commit] - Gets only that commit git rebase -i HEAD~3 - This opens an interactive cherry picking gui Example: git rebase -i HEAD~3 - This gives the option to include what commits run on working branch Example: git branch -f master [tag or commit] - This forces master branch to a commit
docs.title: Advanced feature, selecting commits

docs.title: Table of Contents

docs.text: Can use Emmet shortcuts for html
docs.title: HTML

docs.text: Use more specified elements rather than Divs, not included the tables element MDN Elements also has table elements here Input types MDN such as radio, checkbox, date, email etc. As well as attributes like value, name, placeholder, required etc Dropdown using Select MDN <main> for major components that go on every page navbar header etc <nav> <header> <aside> something like a navbar, call out, or photo <section> creates large sections <article> used for like a blog post <form action=""> google for form elements <input type="" placeholder=""> goes in form, usually use with <label> <footer> <summary> <details>
docs.title: Semantic Elements

docs.text: Use a form to search google results <form action="https://www.google.com/search"> <input type="text" name="q"> <buton>Search Google</button> </form>
docs.title: Form Example

docs.text: Buttons inside form default "type="submit"" change to "type="button"" or something else to change behavior
docs.title: Button

docs.text: Can add CSS inline (not preffered), Style element (add style div in head of document), Add stylesheet (by using code below) <link rel="stylesheet" href="__.css">
docs.title: Stylesheet

docs.text: Properties are used for styling ex: font weight, color, padding CSS common properties MDN Extended CSS properties list MDN
docs.title: CSS Properties

docs.text: Can also create custom properties/variables. Example shows adding a custom property for the color blue :root { --overlay-color: #03a9f4; } <!-- Gets called in Div like this --> color: var(--overlay-color)
docs.title: Custom Property / Variable

docs.text: Common styling properties and usefull sites. Text styling Text decoration shorthand for underline or color Styling Color Names Color Pallete Ideas Border styling MDN
docs.title: Styling

docs.text: Units of measurement for CSS em/rem/px/% etc em (parents size, changes if nested in a loop/list) rem (gets size from root of document) auto
docs.title: Measurements

docs.text: Order of selectors specificity, the more specific css will override the lower ones. * ID (Most specific) * Class * Element Universal Selector, select everything * { color:pink; } Select all elements like h1, h2 or nav h1,h2 { color:purple; } Select every 2nd text input, red border. Uses an attribute selector MDN to sellect all input elements with a type=text input[type="text]:nth-of-type(2n){ border:2px solid:red; } Select a class .test{ background-color:blue; } Select an ID/Label #test{ background-color:black; } Descendant selector, select an anchor tag in a .class .class a{ color:white; } Adjacent Selector, example selects every button that comes after a button on the same level h2 + button { font-size:40px } Direct Child Selector, example selects only the anchors within the footer element footer > a { color:purple; } or footer.class{ color:purple; } Example targeting the "a" item inside of text, inside of showcase when active. .showcase:active .text a{ background-color: black; }
docs.title: Selectors

docs.text: Example of using active psuedo class .toggle.active=looking for active on the toggle .toggle .active=looking for active inside of toggle Section7 vid 76, goes into selecting nth of element. Full MDN list :active :checked :first :first-child :hover :not() :nth-child() :nth-of-type() Example highlight a button inside a post class on hover .post button:hover{ background:color: red; } Nth of example .post:nth-of-type(2n){ color:black; }
docs.title: Pseudo Classes

docs.text: Keyword added to a selector * ::after * ::before * ::first-letter * ::first-line * ::selection
docs.title: Pseudo Elements

docs.text: Position MDN Position Property Values static relative (can change top and sides from where it would be regularly) absolute (removed from flow, can get position from closest ancestor, if no ancestor then the initial containing block. Try by making parent relative ) fixed (always present)
docs.title: Positions

docs.text: w3 Display Property Values w3 Display Prop example Show display on click and hide on click Flex align/center/justify etc
docs.title: Display

docs.text: Can use visibility instead of display:none . display none deletes the item, visibility just hides it in place.
docs.title: Visibility vs Display

docs.text: Transition MDN format for changing speed of transitions. Works well on hover or active. Look into timing functions for ease in animations etc { Transition: (property name) (duration) (timing function) (delay) }
docs.title: Transition

docs.text: MDN transform for rotate, scale, move/translate etc
docs.title: Transform

docs.text: The align-items centers vertical, justify content centers horizontal. ALIGN-CONTENT should be used with WRAP in flex container. display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;
docs.title: Example of Flex

docs.text: Lightbox Photo Gallery w3 Modal photo Gallery w3
docs.title: Lightbox Photos

docs.text: Added in BootstrapCDN , imported into head <!-- Bootstrap CDN https://fontawesome.com/v3.2.1/get-started/ --> <link href="//netdna.bootstrapcdn.com/twitter-bootstrap/2.3.2/css/bootstrap-combined.no-icons.min.css" rel="stylesheet"> <link href="//netdna.bootstrapcdn.com/font-awesome/3.2.1/css/font-awesome.css" rel="stylesheet">
docs.title: Bootstrap

docs.text: Example of a bootstrap button <button type="button" class="btn btn-warning"> Primary <button>
docs.title: Bootstrap button

docs.text: Import Icon in Bootstrap tutorial Facebook CSS for adding Font Awesome Icon, Icon tag inside of toggle. Showing how to select icon and change it between states /* Active state of toggle below, background turns blue on click */ .toggle:active { background-color: blue; } /* Add Font Awesome Icon */ .toggle i:before { font-family: FontAwesome; content: "\f0d7"; position: absolute; left: 5px; bottom: -5px; } /* Change Font Awesome Icon on active state */ .toggle.active i:before { font-family: FontAwesome; content: "\f0d8"; position: absolute; left: 5px; bottom: 3px; }
docs.title: FontAwesome Icon

docs.text: Docker Sandbox docker environment Play with docker A guide on developing React inside of Docker blog Setting up docker in pycharm and vscode Stackoverflow Start with dockerignore echo "venv .venv .git" > .dockerignore Table of Contents Tutorials Docker Commands Flags Build / Run / Push Docker Run Docker-compose Commands Dockerfile Example Jupyter Notebook Dockerfile Docker Django Stack Tutorials Getting started tutorial/Todo app docker run -d -p 80:80 docker/getting-started Docker-compose Docs using Flask, Redis to Count clicks. Docker Commands Docker Syntax: docker {{cmd}} {{flags}} {{image:tag}} {{cmd}} * build * run * exec * ps * images * rmi = remove images * stop Flags -f = File name (defaults to Dockerfile) -t = tag -d = detached -p = port -v = volume -e = environment -it = interactive shell --rm = remove the container once we exit --build-arg SOME_ENV_VAR=hello = Is the build time variable Build and Run and Push Docker Hub Documentation docker build -t coronel08/{{tag-name}} . docker run -d -p {{ports}} --name {{name}} coronel08/{{tag-name}} docker exec -it {{container-id}} bash # if bash fails try sh docker push coronel08/{{tag-name}} Docker Run An example of docker run command to setup a python container docker run --rm -it python:3.8 python docker run --rm -p 8888:8888 jupyter/scipy-notebook Long docker run example, the env in this is used for hotloading. docker run \ -itd \ -- rm \ -v {{${PWD}/folder:folder}} \ -p {{port:port}} \ -e CHOKIDAR_USEPOLLING=true \ {{img_name}} Dockerfile Example Run apt-get update and install. Dont forget to remove cahced data. Also use -y flag when installing Can use either apt-get clean or the rm -rf command to clean RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y\ package1\ package2\ && apt-get clean # && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/* COPY requirements.txt /app/requirements.txt WORKDIR app RUN pip install --user -r COPY . /app Jupyter Notebook Dockerfile Building a Jupyter Notebook Dockerfile Mlinproduction blog FROM jupyter/scipy-notebook ARG SOME_ENV_VAR ENV SOME_ENV_VAR=${SOME_ENV_VAR} RUN pip install awscli --upgrade --user RUN echo 'export PATH=~/.local/bin:$PATHn' >> $HOME/.bashrc COPY requirements.txt ./requirements.txt RUN pip install -r requirements.txt RUN rm ./requirements.txt Build docker build --build-arg SOME_ENV_VAR=hello -t my-jupyter-image -f Dockerfile . Run docker run --rm -p 8888:8888 my-jupyter-image Docker-compose commands up down stop docker-compose up -d --build #build flag recreates the file Docker Stack Docker Flask Stack Dockerizing Flask with Postgres, Gunicorn and Nginx Testdriven.io Docker Django Stack Docker docs Django Dockerizing Django with Postgres Gunicorn and Nginx Testdriven.io
docs.title: Docker

docs.title: Build and Run and Push

docs.text: An example of docker run command to setup a python container docker run --rm -it python:3.8 python docker run --rm -p 8888:8888 jupyter/scipy-notebook Long docker run example, the env in this is used for hotloading. docker run \ -itd \ -- rm \ -v {{${PWD}/folder:folder}} \ -p {{port:port}} \ -e CHOKIDAR_USEPOLLING=true \ {{img_name}}
docs.title: Docker Run

docs.text: Run apt-get update and install. Dont forget to remove cahced data. Also use -y flag when installing Can use either apt-get clean or the rm -rf command to clean RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y\ package1\ package2\ && apt-get clean # && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/* COPY requirements.txt /app/requirements.txt WORKDIR app RUN pip install --user -r COPY . /app
docs.title: Dockerfile Example

docs.text: Building a Jupyter Notebook Dockerfile Mlinproduction blog FROM jupyter/scipy-notebook ARG SOME_ENV_VAR ENV SOME_ENV_VAR=${SOME_ENV_VAR} RUN pip install awscli --upgrade --user RUN echo 'export PATH=~/.local/bin:$PATHn' >> $HOME/.bashrc COPY requirements.txt ./requirements.txt RUN pip install -r requirements.txt RUN rm ./requirements.txt Build docker build --build-arg SOME_ENV_VAR=hello -t my-jupyter-image -f Dockerfile . Run docker run --rm -p 8888:8888 my-jupyter-image
docs.title: Jupyter Notebook Dockerfile

docs.text: Javascript Notes increment = ++ decrement = -- Table of Contents Javascript Notes Closures and Nesting Functions private variable Recursion vs Loop Array Methods splicing slice Sorting Arrays Array Itteration Strip HTML strings Destructuring Conditionals vs Switch vs Ternary Function Closures and Nesting Functions Closures Mozilla function makeAdder(a){ return function(b){ return a + b } } var add5 = makeAdder(5) var add20 = makeAdder(20) add5(8) add20(8) another example function init(){ var private = 'Mozilla' function displayName(){ return private } return displayName() } myInit = init() myInit() best Example can also be redone to use arrow functions var counter = function(){ var privateCounter=0 function changeCount(value){ privateCounter += value } return{ increment:function(){ changeCount(1) }, decrement:function(){ changeCount(-1) }, value:function(){ return privateCounter } } } counter1=counter() counter2=counter() counter1.increment() counter1.value() counter2.value() private variable function secretVariable(){ var private = "secret variable" return function(){ return private } } var getPrivateVariable = secretVariable() console.log(getPrivateVariable()) Recursion vs Loop For Loop below / Iteration function countdown(number){ for (let i=number; i > 0; i--) { console.log(i) } } Recursion below, a recursive function calls itself function countdown(number){ if(number === 0){ return } console.log(number) countdown(number - 1) } Array methods array method chart array method examples Add or Delete an item in an array Can add or delete to an array using pop/push for last items. Shift/unshift for begining of array. Can also add to back of an array by using Length fruits[fruits.length] = "Pineapple" Using ES6, use rest parameter fruits = ["start", ...fruits] Change value of an item by using array index. changes apple to Kiwi var fruits = ['Apple','Orange'] fruits[0] = 'Kiwi' Splicing Using Splice to add new items to an array. Splice(start,del, items) fruits.splice(1,0,"item1") Slice Slice method slices out a piece of an array into a new array. slice(start,stop) Sorting Arrays W3 Sorting Arrays page sort(): Sorts an array alphabetically reverse(): reverse sort random use Fisher Yates Method Highest or Lowest Array Value Sorting Ascending Now points[0] will return lowest value points[points.length - 1] will return highest value var points = [40,100,1,5,25,10] points.sort(function(a,b){return a - b}) Sorting Descending points.sort((a,b) => b - a) Can also use Math.max() or Math.min() Array Itteration Youtube vid on filter, map, find, foreach W3 Array itteration High Order fucntions / array iteration exampels * forEach(): need to learn, check link above * map() * filter(): creates a new array with items that pass filter * reduce(): adds all values * every(): checks if every item passes test/function * some(): check if some items pass test/function * indexOf(): returns index of item looking for * lastIndexOf(): returns last occurence of item * find(): returns value of item that passes test/fucntion * findIndex(): Strip HTML strings strip the html from an element const stripHTMLTags = str => str.replace(/<[^>]*>/g, '') stripHTMLTags (' Me and you ') Destructuring Example below skips b and then defines the rest using rest/spread operator. Based on position const alphabet = ['a','b','c','d','e','f'] const [a,,c,...rest] = alphabet console.log(a,c,rest) A function that returns an array thaat gets deconstructed function testFunction(num1,num2){ return [a+b, a*b] } const [sum, multiply, division='No'] = testFunction(3,4) OBJECT DESTRUCTURING, instead of being based on position it is based on the name of the key. Need to research on how to destructure into a function const person1 = { name:"Frank", age: 32, address: { city: "Los Angeles", state: "Ca" } } const {name, address:{ city }} = person1 function printUser{} Conditionals vs Switch vs Ternary Conditionals w3 . If, Else statements if (time < 10){ greeting="Good morning" } else if (time < 20){ greeting = "Good day" } else { greeting = "Good evening" } Switch w3 . The getDay operator returns a number for the Day. The Switch conditional gives a name to the number. switch (new Date().getDay()){ case 0: day = "Sunday"; break; case 1: day = "Monday"; break; case 2: day = "Tuesday"; break; } Ternary Mozilla var age = 26 var beverage = (age >= 21) ? "Beer":"Juice" Function Function Expression, need to be declared before call const getRectArea = function(width, height){ return width * height; } Function Declaration, can be called at any point function getRectArea(width, height){ return width * height }
docs.title: Javascript Notes

docs.text: increment = ++ decrement = --
docs.title: Javascript Notes

docs.text: Closures Mozilla function makeAdder(a){ return function(b){ return a + b } } var add5 = makeAdder(5) var add20 = makeAdder(20) add5(8) add20(8) another example function init(){ var private = 'Mozilla' function displayName(){ return private } return displayName() } myInit = init() myInit() best Example can also be redone to use arrow functions var counter = function(){ var privateCounter=0 function changeCount(value){ privateCounter += value } return{ increment:function(){ changeCount(1) }, decrement:function(){ changeCount(-1) }, value:function(){ return privateCounter } } } counter1=counter() counter2=counter() counter1.increment() counter1.value() counter2.value()
docs.title: Closures and Nesting Functions

docs.text: function secretVariable(){ var private = "secret variable" return function(){ return private } } var getPrivateVariable = secretVariable() console.log(getPrivateVariable())
docs.title: private variable

docs.text: For Loop below / Iteration function countdown(number){ for (let i=number; i > 0; i--) { console.log(i) } } Recursion below, a recursive function calls itself function countdown(number){ if(number === 0){ return } console.log(number) countdown(number - 1) }
docs.title: Recursion vs Loop

docs.text: Can add or delete to an array using pop/push for last items. Shift/unshift for begining of array. Can also add to back of an array by using Length fruits[fruits.length] = "Pineapple" Using ES6, use rest parameter fruits = ["start", ...fruits] Change value of an item by using array index. changes apple to Kiwi var fruits = ['Apple','Orange'] fruits[0] = 'Kiwi'
docs.title: Add or Delete an item in an array

docs.text: Using Splice to add new items to an array. Splice(start,del, items) fruits.splice(1,0,"item1")
docs.title: Splicing

docs.text: Slice method slices out a piece of an array into a new array. slice(start,stop)
docs.title: Slice

docs.text: W3 Sorting Arrays page sort(): Sorts an array alphabetically reverse(): reverse sort random use Fisher Yates Method
docs.title: Sorting Arrays

docs.text: Sorting Ascending Now points[0] will return lowest value points[points.length - 1] will return highest value var points = [40,100,1,5,25,10] points.sort(function(a,b){return a - b}) Sorting Descending points.sort((a,b) => b - a)
docs.title: Highest or Lowest Array Value
Can also use Math.max() or Math.min()

docs.text: Youtube vid on filter, map, find, foreach W3 Array itteration High Order fucntions / array iteration exampels * forEach(): need to learn, check link above * map() * filter(): creates a new array with items that pass filter * reduce(): adds all values * every(): checks if every item passes test/function * some(): check if some items pass test/function * indexOf(): returns index of item looking for * lastIndexOf(): returns last occurence of item * find(): returns value of item that passes test/fucntion * findIndex():
docs.title: Array Itteration

docs.text: strip the html from an element const stripHTMLTags = str => str.replace(/<[^>]*>/g, '') stripHTMLTags (' Me and you ')
docs.title: Strip HTML strings

docs.text: Example below skips b and then defines the rest using rest/spread operator. Based on position const alphabet = ['a','b','c','d','e','f'] const [a,,c,...rest] = alphabet console.log(a,c,rest) A function that returns an array thaat gets deconstructed function testFunction(num1,num2){ return [a+b, a*b] } const [sum, multiply, division='No'] = testFunction(3,4) OBJECT DESTRUCTURING, instead of being based on position it is based on the name of the key. Need to research on how to destructure into a function const person1 = { name:"Frank", age: 32, address: { city: "Los Angeles", state: "Ca" } } const {name, address:{ city }} = person1 function printUser{}
docs.title: Destructuring

docs.text: Conditionals w3 . If, Else statements if (time < 10){ greeting="Good morning" } else if (time < 20){ greeting = "Good day" } else { greeting = "Good evening" } Switch w3 . The getDay operator returns a number for the Day. The Switch conditional gives a name to the number. switch (new Date().getDay()){ case 0: day = "Sunday"; break; case 1: day = "Monday"; break; case 2: day = "Tuesday"; break; } Ternary Mozilla var age = 26 var beverage = (age >= 21) ? "Beer":"Juice"
docs.title: Conditionals vs Switch vs Ternary

docs.text: Function Expression, need to be declared before call const getRectArea = function(width, height){ return width * height; } Function Declaration, can be called at any point function getRectArea(width, height){ return width * height }
docs.title: Function
